subject: RE: [junit] RE: One test class per class (was Testing multiple interfaces?)
msgSnippet: ... Because every time you decide a class needs to belong to an additional group, you need to implement another interface.  Not a big deal but you end up
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Ilja Preuss

> > @Test(groups = { "check-in", "functional", "database" }) public void
> > testInsertion() { // note that the method doesn't really need to
> > start with "test" }
> >
> > As I said earlier, using marker interfaces to achieve this goal is a
> > stopgap measure that doesn't scale very well
>
> I still don't get that scaling thing.

Because every time you decide a class needs to belong to an additional
group, you need to implement another interface. Not a big deal but you end
up having classes that implement a lot of interfaces which bear little
connection to the actual type of the class.

Besides, it still doesn't let you declare that individual methods belong to
specific groups.

> It also gives you some compile time safety that you didn't
> misspelled a category. Do annotations give you that, too? (No
> criticism implied, I'm just curious.)

No, that's correct. At least in TestNG, where groups are strings.

You could consider something in-between like having annotations that
represent groups:

@GroupFunctional
@GroupDataBase
@Test
public void addRecord() { ... }

but this seems a bit overkill to me compared to

@Test(groups = { "functional", "database" })
public void addRecord() { ... }

Besides, it would also force users to create their own annotations and
figure out a way for the framework to be able to identify them...
